thread.title: New starting lineup helps Utah Jazz end preseason strong
thread.title_full: New starting lineup helps Utah Jazz end preseason strong | Deseret News

author: Jody Genessy
title: New starting lineup helps Utah Jazz end preseason strong
text:
Raul Neto and Rodney Hood inserted into first five in place of Trey Burke and Alec Burks in big win over Denver.
“ I really saw this game like a regular season game for me and for the team — that (it) was important to get ready to go.”
Jazz center Rudy Gobert
SALT LAKE CITY — Before Thursday’s tipoff, Utah Jazz coach Quin Snyder said he wanted to treat the team’s preseason finale as if it were a regular season game.
If the regular season plays out like this one did, Jazz fans should be excited for the next six-plus months.
After scoring the first 14 points, the Jazz finished the exhibition season with a lopsided 98-78 victory over an undermanned Denver Nuggets team at EnergySolutions Arena.
“I like where we were tonight relative to where we were the other night,” Snyder said two nights after giving a riveting and realistic postgame interview in which he detailed how the team must work and strive harder to be an elite team like Oklahoma City.
“I really saw this game like a regular season game for me and for the team — that (it) was important to get ready to go,” Jazz center Rudy Gobert said.
If this indeed was an accurate dress rehearsal for next Wednesday’s season opener at Detroit, the Jazz will have a different starting five than what the team trotted out to begin the first six preseason games.
Rookie Raul Neto replaced Trey Burke and second-year shooting guard Rodney Hood started in place of Alec Burks in the Jazz’s first five.
A sign of what’s ahead?
Snyder said the coaching staff, which is well aware that all of their players would like to start, hasn’t decided yet.
“The thing that we have is a group that I think understands the value that the team is bigger than any one of us and they’re willing to do what needs to be done,” Snyder said. “It’s my job to make some of those decisions.”
Hood finished with as many fouls (five) as he did points (two) and rebounds (three) combined in just 17 minutes. Burks had eight points, five assists and four rebounds in his reserve role.
Burke, who’s played well all preseason after his tough sophomore season, might be an enticing option for Snyder because of his ability to put up points. He scored a team-high 17 points in a sixth-man role after putting up 20 against Russell Westbrook and the Thunder on Tuesday.
Burke gave fans in the arena a thrill during the non-televised game, hitting buzzer-beaters at the end of the first three quarters.
“The one thing that’s clear,” Snyder said, “is that Trey Burke is playing great.”
Neto also played well, finishing with 10 points, two rebounds, one assist and one steal. He was on the court as the Jazz held the Nuggets scoreless for the first five and a half minutes to set the tone.
“It doesn’t matter who’s on the court with me. I like to play,” Neto said. “I don’t care if it’s the starting lineup. I just like to play and enjoy it out there on the court.”
Gobert, who had by far his best preseason showing, was enthusiastic about this revised starting lineup. He thought Neto and Hood added a physical defensive presence in the backcourt and likes how Burke and Burks “give a spark offensively” off the bench.
“I think we played with more intensity,” Gobert said. “Trey is a more offensive guard. And Raul is more of a defensive guard. Everybody’s got his strength. I think Trey can impact the games more from the bench, and I think that was a great idea to put Raul in the starting lineup.”
The Jazz, of course, were forced to go with Plan B at point guard this season because starter Dante Exum suffered a season-ending knee injury while playing for the Australian national team in July.
